text: Detective Kima Greggs awakens in the hospital; Bunk and Cole question her about the shooting.
Greggs identifies Barksdale soldier Little Man from a photo array as one of her shooters but cannot positively identify Wee-Bey.
Detective Herc reports successful arrests of most targeted Barksdale dealers, but notes key enforcer Wee-Bey Brice remains at large.
Facing pressure to close the case, McNulty suggests bypassing BPD command and taking the Barksdale investigation to federal authorities.
Recognizing D'Angelo's growing alienation from his family, the detail plans to interview him again hoping he'll cooperate further.
Avon, Stringer, and lawyer Levy deduce the extensive arrests must stem from a wiretap operation.
Stringer advises bailing out arrested crew members to maintain loyalty, while Levy proposes structured plea deals sacrificing some to protect the leadership.
Stringer convinces Avon to fully insulate himself, relocating operations to the funeral home, with Stringer managing drugs and Brianna managing money.
Avon demands his New York supplier (Roberto) improve heroin quality; Brianna plans to manipulate D'Angelo with promises and appeals to family loyalty.
During interrogation with McNulty and Pearlman, D'Angelo Barksdale provides Wee-Bey Brice's hiding location in Philadelphia.
D'Angelo admits his involvement in Brandon's murder setup and falsely implicates Wee-Bey as the sole shooter in the Deirdre Kresson murder.
D'Angelo expresses disillusionment with 'the game', feeling trapped, and offers full cooperation on the Barksdale organization in exchange for relocation and a fresh start.
Lt. Daniels informs his wife Marla about D'Angelo's cooperation and his plan to bypass Burrell by involving the FBI.
Bunk and Freamon successfully track Wee-Bey Brice to Philadelphia by tracing calls made from the city to Levy's office.
Stringer Bell receives a new heroin shipment and instructs remaining crew on resuming street sales.
McNulty persuades FBI Agent Fitzhugh to consider federal involvement, but Fitzhugh's supervisor (Amanda Reese) ultimately declines.
Undeterred, Lt. Daniels decides to take the case directly to the U.S. Attorney's office, highlighting the political corruption angle.
Violence erupts in the Pit as rival crews test the weakened Barksdale presence; Bodie holds the territory for Avon.
McNulty visits Greggs in the hospital; she absolves him of guilt for her shooting and asks him to look after Bubbles.
Greggs' partner Cheryl leaves the hospital room angrily, frustrated by the discussion of the case she believes isn't worth Kima's life.
McNulty delivers money from Greggs to Bubbles but finds him actively using heroin again, breaking his sobriety.
Bubbles attempts to return some money but succumbs to addiction, taking it all and asking McNulty not to tell Greggs he relapsed.
Detective Herc learns he was passed over for sergeant promotion, with Carver seemingly moved ahead on the list.
McNulty, Daniels, and Freamon present the Barksdale case to the FBI and U.S. Attorney, detailing the link between drug money, real estate speculation, and political corruption.
The FBI expresses primary interest in using the Barksdale case to target corrupt politicians, angering McNulty who feels they disregard the street-level drug impact.
Lt. Daniels confronts Detective Carver, confirming Carver was Dep. Comm. Burrell's mole within the Barksdale detail.
After discovering the mole, Daniels symbolically returns Prez Pryzbylewski (previously restricted) to street duty.
Acting on D'Angelo's intel, Daniels oversees the arrest of Wee-Bey Brice in Philadelphia.
Brianna Barksdale visits D'Angelo in prison, attempting to persuade him to retract his cooperation by appealing to family loyalty.
Major Rawls informs McNulty that the U.S. Attorney complained to Burrell about McNulty's attitude, revealing the attempt to take the case federal.
ASA Pearlman learns D'Angelo has reversed his decision to cooperate and is now represented again by Maurice Levy.
Levy informs Pearlman that the arrested Barksdale members will accept plea deals with predetermined sentences.
In court, Avon Barksdale pleads guilty in exchange for a relatively light seven-year sentence.
Stringer Bell, present in court, smugly congratulates a disgusted McNulty, echoing McNulty's sarcastic remark from Episode 1.
A despondent McNulty refuses to acknowledge Judge Phelan's congratulations.
Influenced by his mother, D'Angelo Barksdale receives the maximum sentence of twenty years after withdrawing his cooperation.
Daniels learns Lt. Cantrell received the Major promotion Daniels was previously considered for.
Back in Narcotics, Herc indoctrinates new detectives, ironically embracing the sophisticated investigative techniques he initially scorned.
Major Rawls allows Detective Lester Freamon to transfer back to his preferred unit, Homicide.
Bodie Broadus takes charge of the Barksdale operation in the towers, while Poot Carr manages the Pit.
During interrogation by Bunk, Wee-Bey Brice readily confesses to murdering Little Man and Nakeesha Lyles.
Wee-Bey also falsely confesses to killing William Gant to protect the actual shooter (Bird), while refusing to implicate Avon or Stringer.
(Montage) Bubbles and Johnny are shown back together, hustling on the streets.
(Montage) Detective Santangelo is shown back in uniform patrol duty in the Western District.
(Montage) Dep. Comm. Burrell formally promotes Detective Ellis Carver to Sergeant.
(Montage) Detective Prez Pryzbylewski clears the evidence board in the now-defunct detail office.
(Montage) Recovering in hospital, Detective Greggs watches a police car chase outside her window.
(Montage) Detectives Freamon and Bunk visit McNulty at his new, punitive assignment: the marine unit patrol boat.
(Montage) Stringer Bell oversees money counting operations at the Barksdale funeral home front.
(Montage) New, young dealers replace the arrested ones in the Pit, highlighting the cycle of the drug trade.
(Montage) Omar Little is shown in the South Bronx, New York, robbing another drug dealer, demonstrating his survival and adaptability.
